snippet: An order by the government to security forces to break up the protests aroused fears of a new round of violent clashes.
abstract: Egypt’s military-backed government instructs its security forces to end two sit-ins by tens of thousands of supporters of the deposed Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi; sit-ins have become nuisances for the government and flash points for the bloodiest confrontations since Morsi’s ouster; many fear decree could lead to a new round of violent confrontations.

byline.original: By KAREEM FAHIM and RICK GLADSTONE
byline.contributor: Kareem Fahim reported from Cairo, and Rick Gladstone from New York. Mayy El Sheikh contributed reporting from Cairo.

lead_paragraph: An order by the government to security forces to break up the protests aroused fears of a new round of violent clashes.

headline.main: Egypt Vows to End Sit-Ins by Supporters of Deposed President
headline.print_headline: Egypt Vows to End Sit-Ins by Supporters of Deposed President

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
